Chapter on Contemplating the Heavens, Part 12, Heaven of the Thirty-three Gods, Part 9
At that time, Åšakra DevÄnÄm-Indra said to the gods:
These gods are heedless and do not truly understand. They do not practice the true Dharma.
I do this for the heedless gods in order to make them leave behind arrogance and heedlessness. I show this transformation.
These gods have already given rise to disgust and their minds are subdued. If I now expound the Dharma, they will definitely be able to believe and accept it.
At that time, Åšakra DevÄnÄm-Indra saw that the minds of the gods were subdued. He told the gods:
Listen carefully, I will explain for you.
Such a man has the greatest power. His appearance is ugly and he can destroy others. He is difficult to defeat. The power of spells cannot subdue him. The gods have no way to deal with him.
There are also superior gods who surpass you, and they are also unable to stop it, let alone you, whose form and strength are diminished and who have no power of mastery.
This man is called Yama's messenger, the messenger of death, who binds all beings with afflictions and karma, binds them and takes them away, leading them to the hells, hungry ghosts, and animals.
There are eight kinds of dharmas that encompass all beings in birth and death.
What are the eight?
First, all who are born will return to death;
Second, there are none who are healthy and not afflicted by illness;
Third, all who are young and strong will return to old age;
Fourth, those who are fully wealthy will become poor;
Fifth, all are due to karma, and all worlds are obtained through karma. They follow karma and according to the good or bad karma they create, they will receive corresponding karmic rewards;
Sixth, all kindness and love will eventually separate, and there is nothing solid or enduring;

Seventh, one's own actions are certain to bring about retribution, with no one else creating and one receiving the fruits, and no one else creating and one receiving the retribution. All dharmas are certain to be like this;
Eighth, in the world, there is no peace in being heedless, and one will certainly experience the fruits of suffering.
These are called the eight dharmas.
Such dharmas revolve in birth and death in the world, arising from causes and conditions.
Such dharmas cannot be resisted by force, and they cannot be subdued by the power of spells.
The messengers of Yama cannot be opposed by force, and they cannot be stopped by the power of spells.
The dharma of birth and death is like this. If a person creates evil, they can inflict immeasurable suffering and pain.
The messengers of Yama can all harm the gods, asuras, humans, dragons, yakshas, pishachas, and so forth, causing these beings to fall into hell, the realm of hungry ghosts, or the animal realm.
At that time, the heavenly multitudes said to Åšakra, Lord of the Devas:
'Heavenly King!
We are not free from the messengers of Yama.
We only wish that the Heavenly King, with skillful means, will enable us to escape the messengers of Yama. We will then follow the teachings of the Heavenly King.'
At that time, Åšakra, Lord of the Devas, said to the heavenly multitudes:
'There is a great skillful means. If one is able to cultivate it, one will not be harmed by the messengers of Yama.
What is the skillful means that can bring freedom?
It is to cut off one dharma;
The one dharma referred to is to cut off negligence.
One should further cultivate two dharmas, namely Å›amatha and vipaÅ›yanÄ.
One should further cut off three faults, namely greed, anger, and delusion.
One should contemplate the Four Noble Truths:
Suffering, its origin, its cessation, and the path.
One should know the five wholesome protections, namely the five sense objects.
There are also six protections, namely the six sense faculties.
One should know the seven right knowledges, namely the seven factors of enlightenment.
Practicing the eightfold noble path, namely right view and so forth.

Knowing the nine abodes of sentient beings, knowing the ten karmic fruits, knowing the eleven cultivations, knowing the twelve sense bases, knowing the thirteen recollections and mindfulness, knowing the fourteen dhyÄnas and well cultivating the mind, knowing the fifteen dharmas, knowing the sixteen inhalations and exhalations, knowing the seventeen intermediate existences and the continuity of the wheel of rebirth, knowing the eighteen elements, knowing the nineteen intermediate existences.
Knowing the twenty abodes of sentient beings in the desire realm, knowing their activities and karma.
Knowing this, one attains mastery.
If gods or humans can know this, they can sever the three evil paths, can give rise to all wholesome dharmas, and gather all wholesome dharmas.
If gods or humans can sever the evil paths, when they die they will not be afraid of the messengers of Yama.
Therefore, one should abandon the conduct of heedlessness. Heedlessness can sever all wholesome dharmas, just like an enemy.

The person who is negligent cannot obtain worldly or other-worldly happiness. Negligence covers people like animals. They are like those who are asleep when they are not asleep. They do not know what should be done and what should not be done, what is meritorious and what is not meritorious, who are friends and who are not friends, who are fields of merit and who are not fields of merit, what should be said and what should not be said. They do not know what is beneficial, what is harmful, what is meritorious, and what is evil. This is called the first evil.
It is the root of all that is not beneficial, harmful, and distressing.
One should cut off negligence. All the gods practice negligence. Why are they not bound by the messengers of Yama?
' At that time, the lord of the gods Åšakra DevÄnÄm-Indra spoke a verse, saying:
'If the gods and humans are negligent, delighting in practicing unrighteousness,
When they reach the time of death, they will see the messengers of Yama.
Negligence is like poisonous harm, abandoned by the wise,
When facing the end of life, there will be no suffering and distress.
The suffering of death through negligence is the greatest pain, while the absence of negligence is the highest bliss.
If one wishes to seek bliss, one should always be free from negligence.
The gods!
Cutting off one dharma means cutting off negligence, which has six types.
What are the six?
When the eyes see forms, one gives rise to a negligent mind, not seeing things as they truly are.
One may see good colors or bad colors, yellow or black, red or white, long or short, square or round.
In this way, worldly people do not truly understand things, and due to negligence, they also do not understand the teachings of transcendence.
With a negligent mind, even if one sees forms, one does not see them as they truly are. One cannot correctly contemplate one's own forms and does not enjoy contemplating the four noble truths.
Among various forms, they see what is unreal as real, and because their minds are heedless, they are unable to contemplate the Dharma of the world and the Dharma beyond the world.
Having heard sounds with the ears, they do not understand their meaning, whether it is singing or speaking, whether it is meaningful or not. They do not understand such worldly meanings.
Whether it is sÅ«tras, geya, vyÄkaraá¹‡a, udÄna, nidÄna, avadÄna, itivá¹›ttaka, jataka, vaipulya, or adbhutadharma, having heard such teachings, they do not understand their meaning.
Because of heedlessness, when their lives end, they are bound by the messengers of Yama and led away.
There is also heedlessness:

Having smelled various fragrances, the nose greedily inhales them, not knowing whether they are the fragrance of flowers or fruits. They do not know how to first offer incense as a gift to the world in this way.
Because of heedlessness, they do not know various fragrances.
Moreover, due to indulgence, they do not know the various flavors:
The flavors they eat, whether sweet, sour, salty, bitter, spicy, bland, rough, or smooth, they do not distinguish.
Because their minds are indulgent, they do not know such worldly flavors and do not know the flavor of the supramundane Dharma.
It is because of indulgence.

Moreover, due to indulgence, they do not know bodily touch, do not perform bodily actions, do not repair their homes, do not cultivate work, and do not do many good deeds. The things in this person's home are not complete.

They do not know what should not be done in the world and do not know what should not be done in the supramundane. They do not associate with the elderly and do not respectfully bow or ask about their well-being.
It is because of indulgence.
The gods!
Moreover, due to indulgence, they do not know the mental phenomena, whether good, bad, or neutral.
Not knowing that at the time of death, when struck by the staff of death, one will experience great suffering, and be helplessly led away by the messengers of Yama.
Therefore, Your Majesty, one should sever one dharma, namely, negligence.
Cultivating two dharmas:
First, Å›amatha;
Second, vipaÅ›yanÄ.
These two dharmas show the path to nirvÄá¹‡a.
Åšamatha can sever born dharmas and unborn dharmas, and bring about tranquility.
VipaÅ›yanÄ is called vipaÅ›yanÄ because it sees the two kinds of bodies, the mind and the dharmas.
These two dharmas are good companions, able to sever three faults:
If one is attached to desires, one is taught the contemplation of impurity;
If one is hateful, one is taught the contemplation of loving-kindness;
If one is ignorant, one is taught wisdom.
These three dharmas counteract three dharmas, preventing one from being negligent again.
At the time of death, one will no longer fear the messengers of Yama.
What are the four noble truths?
The four noble truths are the truth of suffering, the truth of the cause of suffering, the truth of the cessation of suffering, and the truth of the path.
The truth of suffering means there are two kinds of suffering:
First, physical suffering;
Second, mental suffering.
The truth of the cause of suffering refers to the aggregates, realms, and sense bases.
The truth of the cessation of suffering means complete cessation.
The truth of the path refers to the eightfold noble path.
These are called the four noble truths.
Well-guarding the five sense objects means form, sound, smell, taste, and touch, etc.
What are the six protections?
They refer to the six sense faculties - eyes, ears, nose, tongue, body, and mind - well-guarding them in the realm of sense objects.
What are the seven factors?
They refer to the seven factors of awakening, which are like the parts of a person's body, like the parts of a city, and like the parts of an assembly. These are called the factors of enlightenment.
What are the seven?
Namely, the factors of enlightenment of mindfulness, investigation of phenomena, energy, joy, tranquility, concentration, and equanimity.
What are the characteristics of the factor of enlightenment of mindfulness?

It is called mindfulness of the faults of conditioned phenomena, mindfulness of the true truths, and mindfulness of the Dharma of nirvana and cessation. This is called the factor of enlightenment of mindfulness.
What are the characteristics of the factor of enlightenment of investigation of phenomena?
It is to investigate with wisdom.
How does one investigate?
It is to investigate this Dharma with the characteristics of suchness, to contemplate its meaning, to keep its meaning in mind, and to be never apart from it in thought after thought.
Having contemplated it, one further cultivates energy. This is called the factor of enlightenment of energy.
Having contemplated this Dharma, a desire arises in the mind, and one thinks of this meaning and gives rise to joy. This is called the factor of enlightenment of joy.
Furthermore, having contemplated this meaning with the mind, the body and mind are subdued, flexible, light, and joyful, and practice without confusion. This is called the factor of tranquility.
Furthermore, having contemplated this meaning with the mind, using the mind to dwell on and collect the mind, this is called the factor of concentration.
Furthermore, abandoning the concentrated mind and other thoughts, this is called the factor of equanimity.

Such dharmas, whether fruits, wisdom, or cutting off afflictions, are all distinct, and their fruits are also distinct, gradually becoming superior, arising from a single condition, and their functions are each different.
Thus, Heavenly Son!
This is called the seven factors of awakening. If one is mindful, one can abandon negligence.
Heavenly Sons!
How can the eightfold noble path abandon negligence, fear the future, and seek peace and happiness, seeking the path to nirvana?

Right view of the noble truths as they really are, right thought of the noble truths, right speech of the noble truths, right action of the noble truths, right livelihood of the noble truths, right effort of the noble truths, right mindfulness of the noble truths, right concentration of the noble truths.
What is right view?
The meaning of being in accord with the truth as it really is, this is called right view.
What is right thought?
The seeds of mind regarding the dharmas as they really are, the characteristics of the dharmas as they really are, and the equal characteristics, this is called right thought.
What is right speech?
Thinking of the four kinds of verbal karma, abandoning the four faults of speech, and upholding the precepts, this is called right speech.
What is right action?
Abandoning the three kinds of unwholesome bodily actions, and upholding the precepts, this is called right action.
What is right livelihood?
Even to the point of losing one's life, upholding the precepts without abandoning them, this is called right livelihood.
What is right effort?
The mind that recollects and gives rise to diligence towards such meanings is called right effort.
What is right mindfulness?
Recollecting and contemplating the meaning of such dharmas, not forgetting or losing them, is called right mindfulness.
What is right concentration?
With a mind of true mindfulness, single-mindedly recollecting and decisively one-pointed towards such dharmas and meanings, this is called right concentration.
These are called the eightfold noble path of the noble ones. If one can recollect, one will not fear the messengers of King Yama.
Furthermore, contemplate the nine abodes of sentient beings.
Celestial sons!
Also contemplate the ten great earth-like dharmas.
What are the ten?
First, sensation;
second, conception;
third, volition;
fourth, contact;
fifth, attention;
sixth, desire;
seventh, liberation;
eighth, mindfulness;
ninth, samÄdhi;
tenth, wisdom.
These are called the ten universal mental factors, which arise together with the mind, each with its own characteristics.
You should know!
What are the characteristics?
Such dharmas arise from a single condition, just like sunlight.
Such dharmas arise together with the mind, with increasing and decreasing aspects.
What is called perception?
Knowing the characteristics of distinctions is called perception.
What is called volition?
The mind conditions three kinds - wholesome, unwholesome, and indeterminate.
There are also three kinds, namely, body, speech, and mind.
Volition is the basis but has no form.
What is called contact?
The union of the three kinds gives rise to contact, which produces three kinds of feelings, thus it is called contact.
Celestial sons should know!
How do the three contacts produce three kinds of feelings?
Namely, painful feelings, pleasant feelings, and neither painful nor pleasant feelings.
What is called attention?
Gathering and taking up the dharmas is called attention.
What is called desire?
Remembering what is to be done is called desire.
What is called liberation?
Because it can discern,
it is also called faith, because it can believe.
It is also called power, because it can uphold.
What is called mindfulness?
If the mind is not confused and disordered in the object of mental engagement, this is called mindfulness.
What is called samÄdhi?
If the mind is focused on one object, this is called samÄdhi.
What is called wisdom?
Discriminating observation of dharmas is called wisdom.
Celestial sons!
There are also ten kinds of great grounds of affliction. If one accepts and practices such dharmas, at the time of death one will be bound by the messengers of Yama.
What are the ten?
First, lack of faith;
second, laziness;
third, lack of mindfulness;
fourth, a distracted mind;
fifth, foolishness;
sixth, not observing well;
seventh, liberation through wrong views;
Eighth, undisciplined;
ninth, ignorance;
tenth, negligence.
These are called the ten dharmas of the great ground of afflictions, the causes and conditions by which one is bound by the messengers of King Yama, the Dharma that gives rise to defiled existence.
All you celestial sons!
How do I explain the ten kinds of great ground of unwholesomeness?
What is lack of faith?
Lack of faith in liberation.
If one lacks faith in the Dharma of liberation, it is called lack of faith.
What is laziness?
Abandoning diligence is called laziness.
What is lack of mindfulness?
Forgetting the Dharma is called lack of mindfulness.
What is a distracted mind?
The mind is not upright, so it is called a distracted mind.
What is foolishness?
Lacking skillful means in the mind is called foolishness.
What is improper contemplation?
Improper contemplation, thinking of non-Dharma, not practicing the right path, seeing impurity as pure, is called improper contemplation.
What is wrong view?
Grasping at inverted dharmas, firmly attached and unable to let go, is called wrong view.
What is an untamed mind?
Because it is not tranquil, it is called untamed.
What is ignorance?
Delusion regarding the three realms is called ignorance.
What is negligence?
Not performing wholesome actions is called negligence.
These are called the ten kinds of afflictions of the great earth, which are extremely contemptible and evil.
'Heavenly sons!
There are also ten kinds of defiled dharmas of the earth.
What are the ten?ğŸ”½First, anger;
second, resentment;
third, lack of remorse;
fourth, firmness;
fifth, deception;
sixth, flattery;
seventh, jealousy;
eighth, stinginess;
ninth, pride;
tenth, great pride.
These are called the ten kinds of defiled dharmas of the earth.
Why are they called defiled dharmas of the earth?
Because they are included in the great earth, they are called defiled.
What is called anger?
The mind is coarse and evil, therefore it is called anger.
What is called resentment?
The mind is bound and becomes a grudge, therefore it is called resentment.
What is called non-regret?
Gladly committing various evils, rejoicing after committing them, therefore it is called non-regret.
What is called firmness?
Committing evil deeds, clinging to them and not letting go, this is called firmness.
What is called illusion?
Deceiving sentient beings, being deceived by the twelve sense bases, therefore it is called illusion.
Heavenly son, you should know!
What are the twelve sense bases?
Internally, there are eyes, ears, nose, tongue, body, and mind, these are called internal sense bases;
Externally, there are forms, sounds, smells, tastes, tactile objects, and dharmas, these are called external sense bases.
There are two kinds of distinctions:
First, characteristics;
Second, the essence of self-nature.
As for the characteristics,

The eye consciousness arises from the four great elements, and this is called the eye. You should know that the ear, nose, tongue, body, and mind each have their own characteristics in distinguishing objects.
How should one understand the characteristics of one's own body?
As for one's own body, it is called non-inverted.
The eye consciousness arises from five causes and conditions.
What are the five?
Because there is an eye, there is form, there is light, there is space, and there is recollection, the eye consciousness can arise.
The ear is not like this. The arising of the ear consciousness knows both light and darkness, and does not depend on light.
The nose, tongue, body, and mind are also like this.
The mental consciousness, in relation to light, sometimes has a function and sometimes does not.
What is the function?
What is the non-function?
If the eye consciousness sees form, the mental consciousness clearly understands, this is called the function.
What is the function or non-function?
Visual consciousness observes form, if there is no light, then nothing is seen. The other faculties' knowledge does not depend on light. This is called the great consciousness.
Celestial sons!
There are also four great elements that are mutually dependent.
How do the four great elements mutually rely on each other, sometimes increasing and sometimes decreasing?
The eyes increase the great fire;
The nose increases the great earth;
The body increases the great wind;
The tongue increases the great water;
The ears increase the great space.
This dharma increases and excels. In the space of the ears, the mind can grasp sounds.
Therefore, one should know that there is increase and decrease.
Next, observing the entrances:
Which ones are near conditions?
Which entrances are far conditions?
The nose, tongue, and body - these three faculties - know by encountering touch.
What the eyes see is neither near nor far.ğŸ”½What the ears hear, if far, is not clear, if near, can be known, and one can also hear internally.
What the nose smells, if near, can be known, and one can also be aware internally.
Just as when there is a disease in the nose, one can also smell the stench by oneself, and just as when there is wind in the ears, one can also hear the sounds by oneself.
In this way, consciousness is categorized into two kinds - eye consciousness and mental consciousness.
In this way, it is completely included, just as a single fire, depending on what it burns, gets different names, such as wood fire or grass fire.
All consciousnesses are also like this, depending on mental consciousness, each having distinctions.
Heavenly son, you should know this!
Having understood these sense bases in this way, do not be negligent.

Those who practice non-negligence, who are not greedy, hateful, or deluded, when such good people die, they do not fear being bound by the messengers of King Yama, do not see the frightening evil appearances of the wardens of hell, and do not see the evil realms of King Yama.
They do not fall into hell, hungry ghosts, or animals, but always experience peace and joy up to nirvana, accomplishing immeasurable joy and peace and bliss, because of non-negligence.
Furthermore, Your Majesty!
Contemplate the twelve sense fields as impermanent, suffering, empty, and without self, and contemplate their dependence on causes and conditions to arise.
Having contemplated in this way, be free from negligence.
Contemplate the arising of eye consciousness as illusory dharmas, empty and nonexistent, not solid or real, and subject to destruction.
When eye consciousness ceases, it gives rise to ear consciousness, which is empty and nonexistent, not solid or subject to destruction.

In this way, contemplate the six internal sense bases and the six external sense bases, which may arise or cease, are contentious and delightful, subject to decay and impermanence, and arise from causes and conditions.
Know them as they really are. Having seen in this way, do not crave form.
If you see a desirable form, do not give rise to attachment.
Those who are not negligent do not give rise to craving even for the five desires of the heavens, let alone human desires.'
At that time, Åšakra, Lord of the Devas, spoke a verse, saying:
Deluded about the realms and sense bases, obstructing the path to nirvana,
Because of this heedlessness, all wholesome dharmas are lost.
If there are three kinds of faults, they are the servants of the great evil paths,
Ignorance is the worst evil, and because of heedlessness, one transmigrates.
The foolish and heedless practices, death is always in the hands,
If there is delight in heedlessness, everything is destroyed.
If a person passes over one dharma, contemplates two dharmas,
Knows the characteristics of the three realms, that person will then experience happiness.
If the heavenly blessings are exhausted, destroyed by heedlessness,
Falling, deceived by ignorance, no one can save and protect.
One dharma is always supreme, able to endure and practice,
If one is in accord with patience, with compassion for all beings.
When the time of death and fear arrives, one attains such great power,
Therefore, leave heedlessness and diligently cultivate all practices.
If one can abandon ignorance and always guard clear wisdom,
By knowing the clear and the ignorant, heedlessness cannot destroy.
If a person abandons heedlessness, they will certainly attain great benefit.
In this way, if one is not heedless, they will be able to benefit themselves.
Bound by the net of heedlessness, diligent practice brings liberation.
Thus, I have briefly explained the characteristics of bondage and liberation.
If the celestial sons already know, and if there is heedlessness,
When they reach the time of death, they will then know its karmic retribution.'
In this way, Åšakra, Lord of the Devas, extensively explained the characteristics of the twelve sense bases, taming and subduing the celestial sons who were heedless.

If the celestial sons had previously planted wholesome roots, but were slightly heedless, upon hearing this Dharma, they would awaken by themselves, no longer be heedless, and with their faculties matured, would be able to practice it all.
If the faculties of the devas are not yet mature, it is like bursting a raw abscess. When it is burst and washed, it is of no benefit, and it is the same.
Furthermore, the Heavenly King Shakra gradually increases from one, and in order, explains the Dharma of the twelve sense bases.
The characteristics of the twelve sense bases.

Having already manifested spiritual powers in the great assembly of the devas, showing rare events, he causes them to enter in order, fixes their minds on right mindfulness, awakens to the characteristics of causes and conditions, and causes them to be free from negligence and benefit them.
Seeing this transformation, the mind gives rise to disgust.
At that time, Shakra, the Heavenly King, benefits by skillful means, and widely explains the wonderful Dharma for the assembly of devas.
'You devas!
What is flattery?
The mind is not upright, and is firmly attached to birth and death, and is therefore called flattery.
What is called jealousy?
Because of the heat and distress of others, it is called jealousy.
What is called stinginess?
Fearing that one's possessions will be exhausted, one becomes stingy and miserly, thus it is called stinginess.
These are called the dharmas of the defiled stages of the three realms. When distinguished, they are included in the three realms.

Anger, resentment, stinginess, jealousy, and deception are bound to the desire realm. The one dharma of flattery pervades the desire realm and the Brahma heaven. Arrogance and great arrogance pervade the three realms.
All good sons!
These are called the ten kinds of unwholesome great earth dharmas.
There are also ten kinds of wholesome great earth dharmas.
What are the ten?
They are called non-greed, non-delusion, conscience, shame, faith, self-control, heedfulness, diligence, abandonment, and non-harming.
These are called the ten kinds of wholesome great earth dharmas. These ten dharmas each have different characteristics.
As for non-greed, it is the fundamental basis of all wholesome dharmas, just like beams and pillars.
The wholesome root of non-delusion is also like this.
Conscience means to guard oneself and be upright.
Shame is to be ashamed of others.
Faith is the purity of mind towards all dharmas.
Subjugation is the good discipline of body and mind, free from evil dharmas, relying on the cool and refreshing Dharma.
Vigilance is diligently cultivating good dharmas.
Abandonment is the mind's detachment from causes and conditions of action.
Non-harming is not afflicting sentient beings.
These are called the ten kinds of good dharmas of the great earth.
If one's mind thinks of these dharmas, then at the time of death one will not fear death, and will not fear being bound by the messengers of Yama.
Why is this?
Because of subsuming good dharmas.
As explained above, the mind, mental factors, good dharmas of the great earth, and defiled dharmas of the great earth,
are generally called the ten dharmas with their own characteristics.
Furthermore, heavenly sons!
What are called the cultivation of eleven dharmas?
If a bhiká¹£u observes his own body and sees his own body as unlovely, not deluded, and not firmly attached, this is called the first practice.
Furthermore, heavenly sons!
If a bhiká¹£u first accepts what is desired and criticizes it, without savoring it, not attached, not thinking of it, and giving rise to a mind of disgust, this is called the second practice.
Furthermore, heavenly sons!
If a bhiká¹£u is always heedful, not attached to sense objects, and exhausts the fetters, this is called practicing heedfulness.
This is called the third practice.
Furthermore, heavenly sons!
If a bhiká¹£u recollects wholesome dharmas and practices wholesome dharmas.
Such wholesome dharmas can give rise to pleasant karmic rewards. Pleasant causes and pleasant conditions, such as these pleasant karmic rewards,
I will accept them and eliminate unwholesome dharmas.
This is called the fourth practice.
Furthermore, heavenly sons!
Cultivate the joy of rebirth.
What power does feeling have? How does it arise?ğŸ”½What causes and conditions?
What are causes and conditions?
How does it arise?
In this way, let the arising of feeling not be an obstruction.
Contemplate feeling as it is, as impermanent, empty, and insubstantial.
This is called the fifth cultivation.
Furthermore, heavenly beings!
If a bhiká¹£u cultivates the impermanence, suffering, emptiness, and no-self of all conditioned phenomena, and that they arise from mutual causes and conditions, not from a single power,
in this way he cultivates.
Having cultivated in this way, his mind does not delight in it. This is called the sixth cultivation.
Furthermore, heavenly beings!
If a bhiká¹£u thinks like this:
I give rise to wholesome thoughts and wholesome causes and conditions.
Having given rise to this thought, it is destroyed by other thoughts.
The thoughts of impermanence and unwholesomeness that I am now attending to destroy my wholesome thoughts and obstruct my wholesome dharmas.
Constantly attending to such thoughts is called the seventh cultivation.
Furthermore, heavenly beings!

If a bhiká¹£u cultivates the eighth practice, the characteristic of equality, the characteristic of abiding in self-nature, the Dharma is not inverted, because the nature of all dharmas is originally pure.
In this way, a bhiká¹£u further observes himself:
Since I have birth, I will definitely die.
The dharmas of conditioned arising are none other than the three characteristics.
Cultivating in this way, all dharmas are impermanent. This is called the eighth cultivation.
Furthermore, heavenly beings!
What is called the ninth cultivation?
The three roots of affliction have three kinds of antidotes.
Namely, desire, anger, and ignorance.
For those with desire, teach the contemplation of impurity;
For those with anger, teach them to cultivate loving-kindness;
For those with ignorance, teach them to contemplate dependent origination.
This is called counteraction.
Cultivating such contemplation, always keeping it in mind, this is called the ninth cultivation.
Furthermore, heavenly beings!
What is called the tenth cultivation?
Remembering the Buddha's merits and bringing peace to the world, therefore cultivating to benefit oneself, this is called the tenth cultivation.
Furthermore, heavenly beings!
What is called the eleventh cultivation?
